title: PSYC2016: Attention
text:
Alex

Have book open on lectern PC, on second screen

title: PSYC2016: Attention
text: Attention

title: PSYC2016: Attention
text:
All day, the world makes its demands. There’s so much of it, world
begging to be noticed.

– Leila Chatti


This is something many of us love about the world, but also something that we struggle with. My lectures take on the basic issue of why we have issues with this. This is something that fascinates me too, in my daily life, and I do experiments to investigate aspects of it.

title: PSYC2016: Attention
text:
Leila Chatti

Your generation has had this more than any other in human history

title: PSYC2016: Attention
section: “It implies withdrawal from some things in order to deal with others” - William James
text:
“It implies withdrawal from some things in order to deal with others” - William James

This is the part that we sometimes don’t like!





Withdrawing of the mind has Lot of consequences.

title: PSYC2016: Attention
text:
English expressions

Please “pay attention!”
“Sorry, I wasn’t listening”
“Sorry, I missed that.”
“I didn’t notice that.” ::: notes What do you mean you weren’t listening? How come your ears being open isn’t enough? We have limited resources. ::: ## Why?
Why do we need selective attention?
Why do we get distracted?


By the end of these 5 lectures you’ll understand distraction better

During the pandemic. I recognized that 50-minute lecture videos were not the best way to communicate things. Lecturing was very depressing then. So I wrote this mini-text.

title: PSYC2016: Attention
text:
“I can’t be everywhere at once”

Implies selection

title: PSYC2016: Attention
text:
“I can’t do everything at once”

Only have two hands, so there’s a selection requirement to do things.

title: PSYC2016: Attention
text:
Need for selection

Can only be in one place at a time
Can act on only a few things at a time
Can look directly at only one thing at a time
Can only extensively mentally process a limited number of things simultaneously

title: PSYC2016: Attention
text:
Attentional selection

Can look directly at only one thing at a time

Directing gaze is overt attention

Can only extensively mentally process a few things at once

Directing mental resources is covert attention

title: PSYC2016: Attention
section: Can only extensively mentally process a few things at once
text:
Can only extensively mentally process a few things at once
Limited mental resources


You have plenty of resources for low-level visual processing! Once we go through the bottleneck aspect, we can circle back to consciousness.

title: PSYC2016: Attention
section: Just two stimuli can be enough to overwhelm capacity
text:
Just two stimuli can be enough to overwhelm capacity
rapid letter
dualStreamDemoPython3

Recognizing letters seems effortless. And it is effortless, at the conscious level! But that doesn’t mean it’s easy for our brains! Make ISIms short enough that starts to be very hard.

title: PSYC2016: Attention
section: You didn’t get both letters right?
text:
You didn’t get both letters right?

You must not have been paying attention…?
“Paying attention” = devoting your resources to a task.

title: PSYC2016: Attention
text:
Quiz time!

If someone didn’t get both letters right, which common expression most refers to the reason why?

title: PSYC2016: Attention
text: VIGILANCE and LIMITED CAPACITY

title: PSYC2016: Attention
text:
Everyone knows what attention is. It is the taking possession by the mind, in a clear and vivid form of one out of what seem several simultaneously possible objects or trains of thought. Focalization, concentration of consciousness are of its essence. It implies withdrawal from some things in order to deal with others.
-   William James (1890)

The first great scientific psychologist. Do you think I could grow a beard like his?

title: PSYC2016: Attention
text:
Deer


Deer aren’t native to Australia, and you’re unlikely to see them. But that’s not because there aren’t a lot around. They were introduced over a hundred years ago because people thought it would be good to have them hear to hunt and eat. Even in Sydney, they’re in a park near the Georges River.

title: PSYC2016: Attention
text:
Vigilance and chita deer

Article about vigilance in chitas

Show video. Deer aren’t native to Australia, and you’re unlikely to see them.
How do we strike the balance between looking out for important new things coming from anywhere, and focusing on another task we’ve decided on

Interrupt signals
Alt+F4


Computers used to freeze all the time. With a lot of advances in operating system technology

title: PSYC2016: Attention
text:
Does not compute…

Your own operating system isn’t upgraded as often. But on the other hand, it’s had millions of years to evolve. So we rarely freeze.

title: PSYC2016: Attention
text:
Homework: The distraction diary

For when you have ten minutes or more to concentrate on studying or other computer work.

Put your phone on airplane mode.
Turn off notifications on your computer if you know how.
Start the stopwatch (often in Clock in Android).
Press “lap” every time you can’t help yourself and you check social media, the news, or otherwise get off task.

title: PSYC2016: Attention
section: In a future class, bump up the distraction diary to keeping phone on as normal aand recording notification checks
text: In a future class, bump up the distraction diary to keeping phone on as normal aand recording notification checks

section: Are you not going to do it because it’s not cool?

title: PSYC2016: Attention
text: Have you ever tried to sneak up on a wallaby or a kangaroo? They’re not the hardest animals to sneak up on. The haven’t evolved to be very vigilant. Not many predators historically.

Quarto
Quarto enables you to weave together content and executable code into a finished presentation. To learn more about Quarto presentations see https://quarto.org/docs/presentations/.

title: PSYC2016: Attention
text:
Bullets
When you click the Render button a document will be generated that includes:

Content authored with markdown
Output from executable code

title: PSYC2016: Attention
text:
Code
When you click the Render button a presentation will be generated that includes both content and the output of embedded code. You can embed code like this:

1 + 1

[1] 2

title: PSYC2016: Attention
section: Binocular rivalry versus two brief letters
text:
Binocular rivalry versus two brief letters


Rivalry: different stimuli presented to the two eyes

Processed in parallel to a point
Incompatible: Brain expects the same object in both eyes, therefore
Direct competition for a single location, and winner occurs relatively early

Dual letters in different locations

No incompatibility, so processed in parallel until bottleneck
Competition only because high-level processing is limited in capacity

title: PSYC2016: Attention
text:
Consciousness and attention
Global Neuronal Workspace theory: “Attention and consciousness are the same process”
– David Alais’ slide #40 of Consciousness lecture 2

You’re not conscious of anything except what you are attending to. Whereas the Recurrent Processing Theory says you’re conscious of the whole visual field in a rich way. This is a hard part of consciousness to explain, because when we probe what people are seeing, it seems like they’re not seeing much (change blindness)
This actually may be part of the non-selective pathway.

title: PSYC2016: Attention
text:
Homework: The distraction diary
Do it when you have ten minutes or more to concentrate on studying or other computer work.

Put your phone on airplane mode.
Turn off notifications on your computer if you know how.
Start the stopwatch (often in Clock in Android).
Press “lap” every time you can’t help yourself and you check social media, the news, or otherwise get off task.



Try not to think of this as homework, You should be reading the mini-text anyway, so why not let it do double duty as a self-insight exercise.

title: PSYC2016: Attention
text:
All day, the world makes its demands. There’s so much of it, world
begging to be noticed.

title: PSYC2016: Attention
text:
ultrawhelmed sensorium, my self
taxed with being a self, brimming with living’s rowdy mechanics and disruptions unremitting, a thought flits by, then another (an unpaid bill, a jingle’s tenacious refrain)—and, … I attend, as best I can,…
yielding to the most persuasive god, the most recent, to each thing I say Yes? Yes!— zealot of whatever calls me next.

It was actually called “A poem for Sunday” and on a Sunday there can be a joy in this. Mindfulness or living in the moment

title: PSYC2016: Attention
text: But you know what, you don’t have to wait

title: PSYC2016: Attention
text:
Lecture 2

People have known about distraction for thousands of years

Buddhism. Are you a victim of your attentional mechanisms?
Flash a bunch of self-help book images.
animals for millions

“What in this image attracts your attention?” Gradual transition from salience to more goal-directed

My story

Like many others, I spend too much time on social media.
Tried apps that stopped me from using the internet.
Fall off the wagon
The Pomodoro method - preserve the rewards, but delay them so you have more uninterrupted work session.

Come back to dual-letters and explain left advantage

title: PSYC2016: Attention
text:
Chapter 7: location versus feature selection
Feature selection is global. You can’t do it locally!


Global facilitation of attended features is obligatory and restricts divided attention. Anderson et al. They showed this with EEG

title: PSYC2016: Attention
text:
Global neuronal workspace theory


There’s a bottleneck prior to the frontal lobe
If a stimulus gets through, it results in reverberating widespread activity associated with that stimulus

title: PSYC2016: Attention
text: Check Irina slides

title: PSYC2016: Attention
section: Chapter 7: Combinations of features can’t be directly selected
text:
Chapter 7: Combinations of features can’t be directly selected

Features are processed somewhat separately by the brain.
Conjoining them requires a capacity-limited process

title: PSYC2016: Attention
text:
Chapter 7: location versus feature selection
Difficult to perceive cluster of red shapes on left while simultaneously perceiving cluster of blue shapes on right.
The combination of location and feature selection can’t be done.
You can either select a simple feature everywhere (e.g., red objects), or select the stimuli in a particular region, but you can’t combine those two abilities.

title: PSYC2016: Attention
section: Combining location and feature selection can’t be done
text:
Combining location and feature selection can’t be done
Probably because of separation of what and where pathways.

title: PSYC2016: Attention
text:
Binocular rivalry versus dual letters

Binocular rivalry: different stimuli presented to the two eyes

Processed in parallel to a point
Incompatible: Brain expects the same object in both eyes, therefore
Direct competition for a single location, and winner occurs relatively early

Dual letters in different locations

No incompatibility, so processed in parallel until bottleneck
Competition only because high-level processing is limited in capacity
